intro: Mcvaughia, commonly known as the desert aster, is a genus of flowering plants native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, composite flower heads. The plants typically have hairy stems and leaves adapted to conserve water, reflecting their drought-resistant nature. Mcvaughia species often bloom in late spring or early summer, producing vibrant purple or yellow flowers that attract pollinators. These plants are often found in rocky soils and are well-suited to harsh, desert environments.
